occurrences.line_text: And friends to termes of gentle truce entize,
To graunt vnto those warriours truce a whyle;
To stay his hand, and of a truce to treat
The cause of their array, and truce for to desire.
Willd him to stay, and signe of truce did make:
To thinke of that true glorious type of thine,
The Patron of true Holinesse,
Right faithfull true he was in deede and word,
Most like that virgin true, which for her knight him took.
That had such might ouer true meaning harts;
The true Saint George was wandred far away,
And knew well all was true. But the good knight
Though true as touch, though daughter of a king,
Of past: true is, that true loue hath no powre
Of past: true is, that true loue hath no powre
For so misfeigning her true knight to bee:
Plaine, faithfull, true, and enimy of shame,
On which true Christians bloud was often spilt,
But whether dreames delude, or true it were,
True Loues are ofte[n] sown, but seldom grow on ground.
If in true ballance thou wilt weigh thy state:
Well knowing true all, that he did reherse,
But simple true, and eke vnfained sweet,
And looked forth, to weet, if true indeede
Which whenas true by tryall he out fond,
A right good knight, and true of word ywis:
True be thy words, and worthy of thy praise,
But true it is, that when the oyle is spent,
Yet true it is, that long before that day
On firme foundation of true bountihed;
But that sweet fit, that doth true beautie loue,
Too true the famous Marinell it fownd,
In all chast vertue, and true bounti-hed
And their true loues without suspition tell abrode.
And his true loue faire Psyche with him playes,
And trained vp in true feminitee:
To be th'ensample of true loue alone,
Then to reward my trusty true intent,
Great liking vnto many, but true loue to feowe.
That crowne true louers with immortall blis,
And treasures of true loue enlocked beene,
For well she wist, as true it was indeed,
And all true louers with dishonor blotten,
Cambina with true friendships bond
Profest to her true friendship and affection sweet.
And wiuehood true, to all that did it beare;
Then she, ne vnto whom I more true loue did beare.
True loue and faithfull friendship, she by her did set.
Well said the wiseman, now prou'd true by this,
As messengers of his true meaning and intent.
In which these Squires true friendship more did sway,
True he it said, what euer man it sayd,
That I too true by triall haue approued:
Ne euer ought but of their true loues talkt,
Of louers lincked in true harts consent;
And in them bore true louers vowes entire:
That if old sawes proue true (which God forbid)
Euarna, and Menippe true in trust,
Whether old Proteus true or false had sayd,
The Champion of true Iustice Artegall.
True loue despiseth shame, when life is cald in dread.
First in one ballance set the true aside.
True vertue to aduance, shall here recounted bee.
The more to be true Florimell he did surmize.
Like the true saint beside the image set,
So ought all faytours, that true knighthood shame,
True Iustice vnto people to diuide,
Full true it is, what so about our land
Right true: but faulty men vse oftentimes
In signe of true subiection to her powre,
Seruing proud Radigund with true subiection;
And token true to old Eumenias,
Vntill his owne true loue his freedome gayned,
Of his true hart so firmely was engraued,
Of highest Ioue, who doth true iustice deale
With fayned colours shading a true case:
Iealous suspect as true vntruely drad,
To mens subiection, did true Iustice deale:
The true guide of his way and vertuous gouernment.
To weete if it were true, as she had told;
To proue her surname true, that she imposed has.
True is, that I at first was dubbed knight
Knights ought be true, and truth is one in all:
As their true Liege and Princesse naturall;
His studie was true Iustice how to deale,
But in the triall of true curtesie,
Good Knights and Ladies true, and many else destroyd.
And swore to him true fealtie for aye.
To be his Timias, his owne true Squire,
It was his owne true groome, the gentle Squire,
The good Sir Calepine, her owne true Knight,
Simple and true from couert malice free:
Too truely tryde in his extreamest state;
For powre is the right hand of Iustice truely hight.
Yet neuer Turtle truer to his make,
And fittest for to forge true-seeming lyes;
Did closely lurke; yet so true-seeming grace
For he is one the truest knight aliue,
For I loue one, the truest one on ground,
The iustest man aliue, and truest did appeare.
Haile good Sir Sergis, truest Knight aliue,
But by their trueth and by the causes right:
The hoars Night-rauen, trump of dolefull drere,
Bold Radigund with sound of trumpe on hight,
That euer shrilling trumpet did resound;
Where sounding loud a Trumpet from the wall,
And caused streight a Trumpet loud to shrill,
For trumpets sterne to chaunge mine Oaten reeds,
At last the trumpets Triumph sound on hie,
The trumpets sounded, and they all arose,
And trumpets sound to cease did them compell.
Till trumpets sound did warne them all to rest;
To weeten what that trumpets sounding ment:
Playing on shaumes and trumpets, that from hence
The Trumpets sounded, and the field began;
The Trumpets sound, and they together run
The mightie trunck halfe rent, with ragged rift
Being diffused through the senselesse truncke,
Large streames of bloud out of the truncked stocke
The truncked beast fast bleeding, did him fowly dight.
To trusse the pray too heauie for his flight;
Tho vp they gan their merry pypes to trusse,
Who trussing me, as Eagle doth his pray,
Late learnd what harme to hastie trust ensu'th,
That more to mighty ha[n]ds, the[n] rightfull cause doth trust.
Trust me, shall find no greater enimy,
But trust vnto his strength and manhood meare,
And vnto Psyche with great trust and care
Through her maine strength, in which she most doth trust,
Her counsell, if he should her trust in me repose.
Defil'd the pledge committed to thy trust?
Vnto whose trust the charge thereof was lent:
Euarna, and Menippe true in trust,
That fayld the trust, which she in him had plast,
The charge of Iustice giuen was in trust,
Her nearest handmayd, whom she most did trust,
I trust a liue, sith I thee fostred first;
And turn'd the trust, which was in her affyde,
No faith so firme, no trust can be so strong,
A courteous Knight, and full of faithfull trust:
More in his causes truth he trusted then in might.
And who most trustes in arme of fleshly might,
His trustie sword he cald to his last aid,
Eftsoone she said, Ah gentle trustie Squire,
Vpon his voyage with his trustie guide,
Yet did this trustie Squire with proud disdaine
Trew Ionathan, and Dauid trustie tryde;
The trustie Mayd, conceiuing her intent,
His trustie sword, the seruant of his might,
The trustie damzell bearing it abrode
Thus hauing her restored trustily,
She him condemn'd, as trustlesse and vntrew:
With that blacke Palmer, his most trusty guide;
So Guyon hauing lost his trusty guide,
That for his trusty seruaunts doth so strongly fight.
Then to reward my trusty true intent,
With her owne trusty Squire, both full of feare,
That trusty Squire he wisely well did moue
She called forth to her a trusty mayd,
To proue his sense, and tempt her faigned truth.
Suspect her truth: yet since no' vntruth he knew,
The Redcrosse Knight from Truth:
Forsaken Truth long seekes her loue,
And simple truth subdue auenging wrong?
Her truth had staind with treason so vnkind;
Her single person to their barbarous truth,
To teach them truth, which worshipt her in vaine,
To seeme like Truth, whose shape she well can faine,
And stedfast truth acquite him out of all.
As time in her iust terme the truth to light should bring.
For truth is strong, her rightfull cause to plead,
The bloudy-handed babe vnto her truth
And therfore wisht me stay, till I more truth should fynd.
Till that the truth thereof I did outwrest,
Assur'd, ere long the truth to let me vnderstand.
And loyall truth to treason doest incline;
But with glad thankes, and vnreproued truth,
And preacht the truth, but since it greatly did decay.
That truth is strong, and trew loue most of might,
Truth is his daughter; he her first did breed,
Dwelt simple truth in seemely fashion.
Till triall doe more certaine truth bewray.
Suspect her truth, and keepe continuall spy
He closely nearer crept, the truth to weet:
Till time the tryall of her truth expyred:
Gainst all, that truth or vertue doe professe,
In simple truth and blamelesse chastitie,
And inly troubled was, the truth to learne.
And for what cause; the truth discouer plaine.
But simple Truth did rayne, and was of all admyred.
Mongst wicked men, in whom no truth she found,
With which he thresht out falshood, and did truth vnfould.
Did cast about by sleight the truth thereout to straine.
For by no meanes the false will with the truth be wayd.
And iudge, whether with truth or falshood they agree.
But set the truth and set the right aside,
For truth is one, and right is euer one.
More in his causes truth he trusted then in might.
To temporize is not from truth to swerue,
Knights ought be true, and truth is one in all:
And loued simple truth and stedfast honesty.
I will the truth discouer, as it chaunst whylere.
Faith to his knight, and truth to Ladies all,
Drew neare, that he the truth of all by him mote learne.
Yet in my truthes assurance I rest fixed fast.
His cause in combat the next day to try:
O neuer Sir desire to try his guilefull traine.
With trembling hand his troubled pulse gan try;
And with great honour many battels try:
And knightly worth, which he too late did try,
Rather let try extremities of chaunce,
Agreed to trauell, and their fortunes try.
Vntride, is lesse then when thou shalt it try:
She staid not the vtmost end thereof to try,
To weld his naked sword, and try the edges keene.
He answered, that he would try it streight,
And battailes doubtfull proofe their rights to try,
Through hard aduentures deedes of armes to try,
To try her Fortune, and his force assay,
And try in equall field, whether hath greater might.
And try if thou by faire entreatie, can
And euery way did try, but all in vaine:
To practise games, and maisteries to try,
Which whenas true by tryall he out fond,
But after death the tryall is to come,
Another her out boastes, and all for tryall strips.
That of his puissance tryall made extreeme;
But well I wote by tryall, that this same
Till time the tryall of her truth expyred:
But Paridell that had too late a tryall
All which who list by tryall to assay,
The third day came, that should due tryall lend
Whereof to make due tryall, one did take
Thereof make tryall, in my greatest need:
The tryall of a great and weightie case,
Which when in vaine he tryde with struggeling.
Nathlesse he shortly shall againe be tryde,
But euer like her selfe vnstained hath beene tryde.
Too truely tryde in his extreamest state;
And ransackt Greece well tryde, whe[n] they were wroth;
Tryde all her arts, & all her sleights, thence out to wrest.
Their puissance, whylome full dernely tryde:
Tryde often to the scath of many deare,
Ne paine at all; for he so oft had tryde
And goodly well aduance, that goodly well was tryde.
Trew Ionathan, and Dauid trustie tryde;
And tryde all waies, how each mote entrance make
But euermore contrary hath bene tryde,
Hauing oft seene it tryde, as he did teach.
And eke her feete, those feete of siluer trye,
And to their tryed swords them selues betake;
And sent in haste for Tryphon, to apply
For Tryphon of sea gods the soueraine leach is hight.
At last to Tryphon she for helpe did hie,
(This Tryphon is the seagods surgeon hight)
Whyleare by Tryphon was not throughly healed,
Therefore to Tryphon she againe doth hast,
Of all that Tryumph. Then the trompets shrill
With tryumph entertayn'd and glorifyde,
And tryumph in their blood, whom she to death did dryue.
And their proud girlonds of tryumphant bayes
With which she earst tryumphed, now did quail
No seruice, bu tthy safety and ayd;
To tucke about her short, when she did ryde,
Which was short tucked for light motion
Close round about her tuckt with many a plight:
So did these two this Knight oft tug and teare.
And snatch, and byte, and rend, and tug, and teare;
Long while he tug'd and stroue, to get it out,
That both rebutted, tumble on the plaine:
His siluer waues did softly tumble downe,
That downe he tumbled on the durtie field,
That on an heape were tumbled horse and man.
So downe the cliffe the wretched Gyant tumbled;
All in gore bloud there tumbled on the ground,
A trickling streame from high rocke tumbling downe
And cleft his head. He tumbling downe aliue,
And rudely tumbling downe vnder his horse feete fell.
He smote it off, that tumbling on the strand
His carkasse tumbling on the threshold, sent
The carkasse tumbling downe within the dore,
That seemd some perilous tumult to desine,
Abhorred bloudshed, and tumultuous strife,
And fast beside him sat tumultuous Strife:
Tumultuous trouble and contentious iarre,
They gan to gather in tumultuous rout,
As if that there were some tumultuous affray.
Can tune their timely voyces cunningly,
And to my tunes thy second tenor rayse,
Their pleasaunt tunes they sweetly thus applide;
In power of herbes, and tunes of beasts and burds;
And to the waters fall tuning their accents fit.
Of few greene turfes an altar soone they fayned,
From Turkes and Sarazins, which them had stayd;
And oftentimes by Turmagant and Mahound swore.
But thus turmoild from one to other stowre,
Might them oppresse, and painefully turmoile,
The worlds sweet In, from paine & wearisome turmoyle.
And ye faire swayns, after your long turmoyle,
The which they troubled had with great turmoyle.
Of her long trauell and turmoyling paine;
Deuizing, how that doughtie turnament
And goodly taught to tilt and turnament;
And better skild in Tilt and Turnament,
So slyding softly forth, she turnd as to her ease.
So left her, where she now is turnd to treen mould.
My chearefull day is turnd to chearelesse night,
Her loue she turnd to hate, and him before
And mightie strong was turnd to feeble fraile.
The light-foot Squire her quickly turnd around,
So backward still was turnd his wrincled face,
And is the point of death now turnd fro mee,
She him obayd, and turnd a little wyde.
Turnd to the shore, where that same warlike Lord
Only she turn'd a pin, and by and by
And turnd his face away; but she the same
And in his flight the villein turn'd his face,
Which now him turnd to disauantage deare;
She turnd her bote about, and from them rowed quite.
But that their blisse he turn'd to balefulnesse:
That sayd, her round about she from her turnd,
Thrise she her turnd contrary, and returnd,
Hee turnd againe, and chearefull looks as earst did shew.
To sorrow huge she turnd her former play,
His wicked fortune, that had turnd aslope,
And loue to frenzy turnd, sith loue is franticke hight.
She turnd her selfe backe to her wicked leares
She turnd, and semblaunce of faire fight did make;
Once hauing turnd, no more returnd his face,
Ay when to him she cryde, to her he turnd,
But all in vaine: and then turnd to the heard,
Then was he turnd into a snowy Swan,
For whom he turnd him selfe into a Steare,
He turnd him selfe into a Dolphin fayre;
He turnd himselfe into a fruitfull vine,
And some that would seeme wise, their wonder turnd to dout.
But with stout courage turnd vpon them all,
As fayning choler, which was turn'd to cold:
Whose fire were better turn'd to other flame;
But turnd her face, and fled away for euermore.
And turn'd his face away, as he did stand,
To Artegall he turn'd, and went with him throughout.
And turn'd aside for shame to heare, what he did tell.
She turn'd her loue to hatred manifold,
So backe againe they homeward turnd their feete.
With that she turn'd her head, as halfe abashed,
But the false mayden shortly turn'd againe
And turn'd the trust, which was in her affyde,
With that in rage she turn'd from him aside,
She turnd her head aside, as nothing glad,
Haue turn'd himselfe, he with his yron flayle
That backe she would haue turnd for great affright.
And sure he had her slaine, had she not turnd her way.
Which I expected long, now turnd to sad annoy?
That they to pitty turnd their former rage,
He to him turnd with furious intent,
But turn'd abacke, and to retyre him hasted
So humbly taking leaue, she turnd aside,
Were turnd, and they to freedome did retyre.
Sternely he turnd againe, when he him strooke
So likewise turnde the Prince vpon the Knight,
Armed to point, sought backe to turne againe;
His grasping hold, and from her turne him backe:
But who can turne the streame of destinee,
But to the wood she goes, to serue her turne,
But he them spying, gan to turne aside,
And euery tender part does tosse and turne:
He would them gazing blind, or turne to other hew.
And to the beast gan turne his enterprise;
They turne themselues, at Vnaes meeke request,
Or backward turne his course from heauens hight;
O let me not (quoth he) then turne againe
That feared chance from her to turne away;
His owne two hands, for such a turne most fit,
So can he turne his earnest vnto game,
Whose freedome shall thee turne to greatest scath.
Soone it must turne to earth; no earthly thing is sure.
Would they once turne, but kept on as afore:
O turne thy rudder hither-ward a while:
The Prince of grace, to let him runne that turne.
To weet if they would turne backe to that place:
Least that it should her turne to foule repriefe,
And darkesome night he eke could turne to day:
To turne into a massy habergeon,
It fortuned (so time their turne did fit)
O when will day then turne to me againe,
And turne his arrowes to their exercize:
At last in vaine was forst to turne his flight,
To turne his steede about, or sure he should be ded.
Turne we our steedes, that both in equall tilt
And but God turne the same to good soothsay,
Which if ye please, to yonder castle turne your gate.
To turne your course, I would to heare desyre,
To turne she doth refuse.
A fit occasion for his turne to find:
Ne wist he how to turne, nor to what place;
His expectation to despaire did turne,
Ye will me now with like good turne repay,
Last turne was mine, well proued to my paine,
And turne both him and her to honour in this wise.
That mortall foes doe turne to faithfull frends,
Albee his turne were next; but stood there still,
That ere she backe could turne to taken heed,
They from them selues gan turne their furious ire,
They turne to that, whereof they first were made?
And turne we here to this faire furrowes end
In hope ye will not turne misfortune to my blame
But none she found so fit to serue that turne,
One of those two, and force him turne his face;
That O ye heauens defend, and turne away
And turne we to the noble Prince, where late
To turne her eyes from his intent away:
Begins to turne, and sunne to shine more bright,
That forst her turne againe in her despight,
But turne we now to noble Artegall;
Now turne againe (Sir Artegall then sayd)
They turne afresh, and oft renew their former threat.
And turne to ill the thing, that well was ment.
And turne thee soone to him, of whom thou art defyde.
And turne we backe to good Sir Calidore;
He forced was to turne from him and fly:
For his owne turne, yet inly neate and clene,
Bidding him turne againe, false traytour knight,
But turne we now backe to that Ladie free,
And from you turne the loue of men to hate.
That he which way to turne him scarcely wist:
Now turne againe my teme thou iolly swayne,
I shal resolue, or backe to turne againe,
And made great mone for that vnhappy turne.
And turne we backe to Calidore, where we him found.
And fierce assailing forst him turne againe:
Himselfe too nigh at hand, but turned wyde
There was Ixion turned on a wheele,
The wrathfull beast about him turned light,
So turned her about, and fled away apace.
That turned all her pleasance to a scoffing game.
And turned vpsidowne, to feede his eye
Now turned into figures hideous,
To which he turned in his wrathfull stound,
To get a snatch, when turned is his face.
The faire Adonis, turned to a flowre,
She turned her contrarie to the Sunne,
To him he turned, and with rigour fell
Which turned hath great mirth, to mourning sad,
He turned backe, and would haue fled arere;
That, were it not for shame,---So turned from him wroth.
She turned her, and returned backe againe:
And eft them turned both againe to fight;
Vnto those woods he turned backe againe,
By all that dying to it turned be?
Of their vaine prowesse, turned to their proper bale.
That backe againe vpon themselues they turned,
After long search and chauff, he turned backe
Temper his griefe, and turned it to cheare,
Turned his steede about another way,
Vpon him turned, and with greedie force
Against the Turneiment which is not long.
That hither turnes his steps. So few there bee,
Good turnes be counted, as a seruile bond,
All which successiuely by turnes did raine;
Do serue their turnes: here I a while must stay,
And painefull pleasure turnes to pleasing paine.
And answering their wearie turnes around,
Turnes him about with fell auengement;
Fowle Gealosie, that turnest loue diuine
Of that great turney, which was blazed brode,
The morrow next the Turney gan anew,
He in an open Turney lately held,
In that late Turney for the snowy maide;
In open turney, and by wrongfull fight
where turney many knights:
So as they courst, and turneyd here and theare,
That lately turneyd, had the wager wonne:
A solemne feast, with publike turneying,
Satyrane makes a Turneyment
Vnto the place of turneyment they came;
Had left that Turneyment for beauties prise,
Whome they had lost in Turneyment of late,
From turning backe, and forced her to stay:
And turning fierce, her speckled taile aduaunst,
She turning backe with ruefull countenaunce,
Then turning to his Lady, dead with feare her found.
Thence turning backe in silence soft they stole,
And turning wrathfull fire to lustfull heat,
And turning backe, gan fast to fly away,
But Satyrane with strokes him turning, staid,
Then turning to his Palmer said, Old syre
And turning to that place, in which whyleare
Against themselues turning their wrathfull spight,
But turning said to Trompart, What foule blot
Against him turning all his fell intent,
And turning to that woman, fast her hent
Turning about he saw that wretched Squire,
And passed fairely forth. He turning taile,
Then Mammon turning to that warriour, said;
At last him turning to his charge behight,
Then turning to the Palmer, he gan spy
Tho turning to those brethren, thus bespoke,
Then backe againe turning his busie hond,
Tho turning soft aside, he did inquire,
